response.content: Thank you, Jeroen Hamstra for the rating. The course is not for total beginners, it is for web developers who want to transfer their workloads into docker containers.

response.content:
Hello Jasondrane Drane,
I would object to the given comment, as the course consists of mainly practical examples, with a few lectures in the beginning explaining the basics. I am open to discussion on what you might consider as an improvement.

Best,
Nevyan

results.content:
pro:
- Sprache leicht verständlich
- jeder Befehl wurde besprochen

contra:
- Keine fortlaufende Struktur (wir installieren mal mysql:latest, dann mysql:8.0) mal hier mal da... Warum???
- In den Unterlagen fehlt der Teil, der sich mit Laravel beschäftigt
- Häufig werden vermeidbare Tippfehler live im video  korrigiert -> schlecht vorbereitet.
- Meine Frage wurde falsch beantwortet
- Min 5.35 im Laravelabschnitt wird  php:7.3.10-apache-strech eingebunden. Das ist FALSCH! es muss php:7.3.10-apache-stretch heißen (im stretch fehlte das t) Der Fehler wird in dem video aber nie geändert. Super ägerlich!
- warum wird mal 'links' mal 'depends_on' benutzt? 
- warum wird die Syntax im docker-compose.yml - File für die gleiche Einstellung unterschiedlich benutzt?
- warum wird manchmal ein Speicherplatz außerhalb des Containers eingebunden, dann wieder nicht und am Ende folgt dann sowas:
volumes:
   dbdata:
ohne Erklärung......
I'm done with this.
- oft wird sudo benutzt, obwohl es überhaupt nicht nötig ist.

Conclusion:
wenigstens habe ich nur 12€ für den Kurs rausgeschmissen. 
thump down

response.content:
Dear Georg,
thank you for your time to write a detailed review. It is appreciated and here is my response to your questions:
As noted in the course description, there is not always an immediate logical link between the videos just because they are setting up different programming environtments.
About the mysql:latest or specific version, it is better to install a specific version, so the container stays immutable to image version changes, this way we can be sure that the configuration will be working on the chosen version.
As mentioned once again in the course description my opinion is that the videos should not be meant to be perfect: as in real life, students shouldn't be scared if they encounter a few mistakes.
You are right, I missed one 't', and I will soon upload the missing Laravel project files.
Clarifications:
'links' is to be able to connect the Laravel application container to the database service container by only using the database container name.
'depends_on' is to be able to have somewhat control over the order of the creation of containers.
In the setup we use:
- a named volume (mysql) - it will be created entirely inside the container and that's where we will be storing our database information.
- and a bind mount (pointing outside of the container) for our development Laravel files, which are residing on our local machine.

I hope you are satisfied now, and if there are more questions, I will be glad to answer.

Best,
Nevyan
response.content_html:
Dear Georg,
thank you for your time to write a detailed review. It is appreciated and here is my response to your questions:
As noted in the course description, there is not always an immediate logical link between the videos just because they are setting up different programming environtments.
About the mysql:latest or specific version, it is better to install a specific version, so the container stays immutable to image version changes, this way we can be sure that the configuration will be working on the chosen version.
As mentioned once again in the course description my opinion is that the videos should not be meant to be perfect: as in real life, students shouldn't be scared if they encounter a few mistakes.
You are right, I missed one 't', and I will soon upload the missing Laravel project files.
Clarifications:
'links' is to be able to connect the Laravel application container to the database service container by only using the database container name.
'depends_on' is to be able to have somewhat control over the order of the creation of containers.
In the setup we use:
- a named volume (mysql) - it will be created entirely inside the container and that's where we will be storing our database information.
- and a bind mount (pointing outside of the container) for our development Laravel files, which are residing on our local machine.

I hope you are satisfied now, and if there are more questions, I will be glad to answer.

Best,
Nevyan
